caption: Table 1: Examples of hateful and abusive instances in AfriHate. All hateful posts are assigned targets.
description: This table presents examples of hate speech and abusive language from the AfriHate dataset, showcasing the diversity of forms and targets across different African languages. Each example includes the original text, a translation, and a label indicating whether the text is hateful or abusive, along with a target category identifying the group or characteristic being attacked (e.g., gender, ethnicity, politics).  The inclusion of targets highlights how hate speech is often directed against specific groups or characteristics within the social context.

caption: Table 2: Information about the AfriHate languages: their ISO codes, subregions, countries in which they are mainly spoken, and the writing scripts included in AfriHate.
description: This table provides details on the fifteen African languages included in the AfriHate dataset.  For each language, it lists the ISO 639-3 code, the subregion of Africa where it's primarily spoken, the specific countries where it's used, and the writing script(s) used in the dataset.

caption: Table 3: Number of keywords used for data collection. For Algerian Arabic (arq), the collection includes controversial topics that are neither hateful nor offensive.
description: This table presents the number of keywords used to collect data for each of the 15 languages included in the AfriHate dataset.  The keywords were used to identify hate speech and abusive language in tweets.  Note that for Algerian Arabic (arq), the data collection strategy included controversial topics that are not necessarily hateful or abusive, reflecting the diverse nature of potentially problematic online language.

caption: Table 4: Collection and annotation details for the AfriHate dataset. The table shows if the data was manually collected, whether a pre-annotation step was conducted, the total number of annotators, the number of annotators per instance, and the inter-annotator agreement (Free-Marginal Multirater Kappa).
description: Table 4 details the data collection and annotation process for the AfriHate dataset.  It shows for each language whether data was collected manually or through other means, if a pre-annotation step was used to address class imbalances, the number of annotators involved per language, how many annotators reviewed each instance, and finally, the level of agreement between annotators (using the Free-Marginal Multirater Kappa statistic). This gives the reader insight into the quality and reliability of the data.

description: This table presents the distribution of data instances across three classes (Hate, Abusive, and Neutral) for each of the 15 languages included in the AfriHate dataset.  It shows the count of tweets categorized as expressing hate speech, abusive language, or neither. This allows for an understanding of class imbalance within each language's dataset.

caption: Table 6: Data distribution of hate speech targets in AfriHate.
description: This table shows the distribution of hate speech targets across different attributes within the AfriHate dataset.  For each of the 15 languages included in the dataset, it breaks down the number of hate speech instances targeting individuals or groups based on their disability, ethnicity, gender, politics, religion, or other characteristics. This provides insight into the types of hate speech prevalent in different African languages and regions.

caption: Table 8: Model performances after fine-tuning BERT-based LMs. The best performance for each language is highlighted in bold.
description: This table presents the performance of various BERT-based language models after fine-tuning on monolingual and multilingual datasets.  The models were evaluated on 15 African languages. The table shows the macro F1 score for each model on each language. The best-performing model for each language is highlighted in bold, allowing for easy comparison of model effectiveness across different languages and dataset types.

caption: Table 9: Macro F1 scores per class for monolingual and multilingual AfroXLMR-76L [only one run] vs. GPT-4o [prompt template 1; 20 shots]. The best performance for each language is highlighted in bold.
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of monolingual and multilingual AfroXLMR-76L and GPT-4 (using prompt template 1 with 20 shots) in classifying hate speech and abusive language across different African languages.  The Macro F1 scores for each language and class (Hate, Abusive, Neutral) are shown.  The best-performing model for each language is highlighted in bold, revealing the relative strengths of the models across different languages and levels of linguistic complexity.

caption:
Table 10: Model performance (Macro F1-score) for zero- and-few shot classifiers across the different languages in AfriHate.
The best performance for each language is highlighted in bold. This is an average over 5 prompt templates.
description: This table presents the macro F1-scores achieved by various models on the hate speech detection task using the AfriHate dataset.  It compares the performance of zero-shot and few-shot learning approaches across different models and for different languages.  The zero-shot results indicate the performance without any training examples, while the few-shot results show performance with a small number of training examples (5, 10, and 20).  The results are averages across five different prompt templates for each model.  The best performance for each language is highlighted in bold.

caption:
Table 11: Model performance (Macro F1-score) for zero- and few shot classifiers across the 14 languages in AfriHate.
Best performance for each language is highlighted in bold.
description: Table 11 presents the Macro F1-scores achieved by various models (including fine-tuned BERT-based models, SetFit with BERT, and prompted LLMs) on the hate speech and abusive language detection task.  The results are broken down by language and whether zero-shot or few-shot learning techniques were used.  The best performing model for each language is highlighted in bold, allowing for easy comparison across different model architectures and language settings.
